replies.body: Just a question question for a Rioter since you're here, but what language do you guys use to program league? Have a great night, can't wait to see what's in store for 4.7!

I've seen this question pop up a number of times, so I'll see if I can answer it:

The short answer is that they use many, many different languages. The longer answer is that they use whatever language they think is best for the task at hand. I believe I recall someone saying they use C++ (or was it C#?) for the in-game client (don't take my word for it). They obviously use a lot of ActionScript/Flex for the PVP.net client (which runs in adobe AIR). They probably use a large number of scripting languages on the server-side. And if they ever just need a little tool to help them with daily work, then they can make that in whatever language they see fit.

In addition to that though, they also use a number of frameworks, such as Scaleform which does part of the graphics for the in-game client. Maestro is a little thing they use to coordinate the different parts of the client. And I believe they also use some things like Hadoop for their web development.

I hope that answers your question. And hopefully I didn't crush you with the wall of text. :P

Obligatory Disclaimer: I didn't check my facts. It's just what I remember from reading other Riot responses in the past. If anything I said was incorrect, I apologize profusely.

*-Scampers away-*

{{summoner:6}}

That's not a bad summary. I can be a bit more specific:

We try to be pragmatic about language and framework use, i.e. - use the best tool for the job. So, we use **C/C++** for the game client and game server. The pvp.net launcher uses **ActionScript**.

For server-side, we primarily use *Java* except for the game server itself, which as mentioned is in C/C++. So the login servers, match-making servers, champ select, and so on are all Java. We use a fairly typical open source enterprise Java stack of software there.

For our websites, many still use **PHP** though we increasingly use a variety of languages and tools for our websites. Many are statically generated using a PHP framework. Others have **node.js** backends for APIs and leverage **JavaScript** for dynamic content (these forums are an example of that tech).

And then we have a host of other languages and tools. We use big data frameworks like hadoop and hbase. For our DevOps and server management work, we use a lot of **Ruby** and contribute heavily to the open source **Chef** framework for server management. Some game tools are written in **C#** and some monitoring and scripting use **Python**. I've even seen a little **Scala** and **Go Lang** show up in the repos.

I'm always happy to answer any engineering related questions!
Have wondered that, and  now feel lucky to be fluent in C# at this moment :P. Cheers for the answer!{{summoner:13}}

What's up?
Mostly thinking about improvements to one of my python projects, but trying to also figure out if I want to set up the PS2 to play some old games.

Ooo, Python. Sounds interesting. Is it something for work, or for play, or for, uh, something in between (idk)?

As for old games, I personally find it hard to go back to old haunts. I know I really enjoyed old games, but at the same time, I know I was like 12-years-old back then and that the quality of games has improved steadily since. Nowadays, those games would probably bore me to death, right? I guess I don't want to ruin any nostalgia. But anyhow, I can certainly relate to the dilemma.

I do remember a particular hotwheels game for the PS2 where you raced cars AND fought with mounted weapons. They even had a couple different game modes, a nice set of levels, and a good campaign mode. Good times.

Right now the Python code is for fun :)  I typically have a few projects I work on throughout the week.

I'm thinking about revisiting old favorites of mine : Frequency/Amplitude. Some of the best music games to be developed.

Hmm yeah. Good music games seem to be few and far between. (Maybe they just don't get as much publicity?) I liked one called Sequence, where they fit the typical hit-arrow-keys-in-rhythm gameplay into a kind of combat with a defensive, offensive, and regen track. And around that was a set of RPG elements, including a decent story. I should really go back and finish it, hmm.

Also, did you know Harmonix is making with a rhythm-based FPS called Chroma? (Yeah, I looked up Frequency on Wikipedia.)

Ello! Just finished an ARAM while procrastinating on my Creative Writing Final, so I know the feel. As well as welcome the additional distraction (better than imgur at least, lol) XD

I'm assuming your not the only one on the Riot side up late for last minute tune-ups for 4.7?

Nope nothing really from the security side of the 4.7 deploy :) 

What was your creative writing final on?

Free subject, but required to be <1000 words. So I have to keep it small but well said. Going with a father with a checkered past answering a simple, innocent question for his very young daughter that brings up memories. Nothing big, going right for the feels :P
Sounds interesting, best of luck! I've always been terrible with creative writing projects.  Guess that's why I studied computer science :P

And I have been horrible at computer science projects! lol, although as an engineering student I'll have to get over that =)

Also, Thank you!

If you can get past all the fundamentals, computer science isn't too bad. I would think that at the start, it would be rough to get used to the raw level of abstract thought and math-like logical thinking required. There's a lot of weird things that you have to just start understanding before you can really get to the good stuff where you piece it all together. After you figure out the fundamentals though, I would think that it would become more natural if you do a lot of writing. Because when you think about it, writing and computer science (and engineering in general) both involve an awful lot of orchestrating different pieces to work together and creating one bigger picture that flows elegantly. Although, the devil really is in the details for computer science, as well.

I dunno. Those are just my 1AM thoughts on the matter. Don't take anything I said to seriously. ;)
